instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, no fan.
threads.message:
Hello there fellow repair technicians,

I am seeking an advice on how to proceed with this board.  [LIST=1]
[*]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3HOT</SIGNAL> -12.5V
[*]PP3V3 on L7260 - fluctuating low voltage 0.1-0.3V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> on L7220 Fluctuating 0.7-3V
[*]<SIGNAL>5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> - fluctuating 0.5V-3V
[/LIST] <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> looks nice and clean. No water damage on the board or other components.

Thank you very much!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, no fan.
threads.message: Seems like something is shorted. <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is coming on so power sequence is starting. Check all rails for shorts and check <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> for pulsing too. Any other rails pulsing?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light, no fan.
threads.message:
Fixed!
Was a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_3S</SIGNAL> rail.
Measured a short on pin 2 of L7260.
Injected 5v on pin 2 and <CAPACITOR>C6213</CAPACITOR> started to heat up.
Replaced <CAPACITOR>C6213</CAPACITOR> and everything is working like a charm again.
Easy peazy lemon squeezy.
Thanks for your help!
